column1: Suzhou (Chinese: 苏州; Suzhounese pronunciation: [səu tsøʏ]
column2: Standard Mandarin pronunciation: [sú.ʈʂóu])
column3: alternately romanized as Soochow
column4: is a major city located in southeastern Jiangsu Province of East China
column5: about 100 km (62 mi) northwest of Shanghai. It is a major economic center and focal point of trade and commerce
column6: and the second largest city in the province
column7: after its capital Nanjing. The city is situated on the lower reaches of the Yangtze River and the shores of Lake Tai and belongs to the Yangtze River Delta region. Administratively
column8: Suzhou is a prefecture-level city with a population of 4.33 million in its city proper
column9: and a total resident population (as of 2013) of 10.58 million in its administrative area. Its urban population grew at an unprecedented rate of 6.5% between 2000 and 2014
column10: which is the highest among cities with more than 5 million people.Founded in 514 BC
column13: with an abundant display of relics and sites of historical interest. Around AD 100
column15: it became one of the ten largest cities in the world mostly due to emigration from Northern China. Since the 10th-century Song dynasty
column16: it has been an important commercial center of China. During the Ming and Qing dynasties
column20: as well as the largest non-capital city in the world
column21: until the 1860 Taiping Rebellion. When Li Hongzhang and Charles George Gordon recaptured the city three years later
column22: Shanghai had already taken its predominant place in the nation. Since major economic reforms began in 1978
column23: Suzhou has become one of the fastest growing major cities in the world
column24: with GDP growth rates of about 14% in the past 35 years. With high life expectancy and per capita incomes
column25: Suzhou's Human Development Index ratings is roughly comparable to a moderately developed country
column26: making it one of the most highly developed and prosperous cities in China.Suzhou is also one of the top 50 science cities in the world by scientific research as tracked by the Nature Index
column27: and home to multiple major universities in China
column29: Suzhou University of Science and Technology and Changshu Institute of Technology.

column2: stone bridges
column3: pagodas
column4: and meticulously designed gardens have contributed to its status as one of the top tourist attractions in China. The Classical Gardens of Suzhou were added to the list of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1997 and 2000. Suzhou is often dubbed the "Venice of the East" or "Venice of China".

column2: a settlement known as Gusu after nearby Mount Gusu (simplified Chinese: 姑苏山; traditional Chinese: 姑蘇山; pinyin: Gūsūshān) became the capital of the state of Wu. From this role
column3: it also came to be called Wu as well. In 514 BC
column4: King Helü of Wu established a new capital nearby at Helü City and this grew into the modern city. During the Warring States period
column5: Helü City continued to serve as the local seat of government. From the areas it administered
column6: it became known as Wuxian (lit. "Wu County") and Wujun ("Wu Commandery"). Under the Qin
column7: it was known as Kuaiji after its greatly enlarged commandery
column8: which was named for the reputed resting place of Yu the Great near modern Shaoxing in Zhejiang.

column1: The name "Suzhou" was first officially used for the city in AD 589 during the Sui dynasty.Su (蘇 or 苏) in its name is a contraction of the old name Gusu. It refers to the mint perilla (shiso). The zhou 州 originally meant something like a province or county (cf. Guizhou)
column2: but often came to be used metonymously for the capital of such a region (cf. Guangzhou
column3: Hangzhou
column4: etc.). Suzhou is the Hanyu Pinyin spelling of the Putonghua pronunciation of the name. Prior to the adoption of pinyin
column5: it was variously romanized as Soo-chow
column6: Suchow
column7: or Su-chow.

column2: the cradle of Wu culture
column3: is one of the oldest towns in the Yangtze Basin. By the Spring and Autumn period of the Zhou
column4: local tribes named the Gou Wu are recorded living in the area which would become the modern city of Suzhou. These tribes formed villages on the edges of the hills above the wetlands surrounding Lake Tai.

column1: Sima Qian's Records of the Grand Historian records traditional accounts that the Zhou lord Taibo established the state of Wu at nearby Wuxi during the 11th century BC
column2: civilizing the local people and improving their agriculture and mastery of irrigation. The Wu court later moved to Gusu within the area of modern Suzhou. In 514 BC
column3: King Helü of Wu relocated his court nearby and called the settlement Helü City after himself. His minister Wu Zixu was closely involved with its planning and it was this site that grew into present-day Suzhou. The height of his tower on Gusu Hill (Gusutai) passed into Chinese legend. In 496 BC
column4: King Helü was buried at Tiger Hill. In 473 BC
column5: Wu was defeated and annexed by Yue
column6: a kingdom to its southeast; Yue was annexed in turn by Chu in 306 BC. Remnants of the ancient kingdom include pieces of its 2
column7: 500-year-old city wall and the gate through it at Pan Gate.

column1: The city was originally laid out according to a symbolic three-by-three grid of nine squares
column2: with the royal palace occupying the central position.During the Warring States period
column3: Suzhou was the seat of Wu County and Commandery. Following the Qin Empire's conquest of the area in 222 BC
column4: it was made the capital of Kuaiji Commandery
column5: including lands stretching from the south bank of the Yangtze to the unconquered interior of Minyue in southern Zhejiang. Amid the collapse of the Qin
column6: Kuaiji's governor Yin Tong attempted to organize his own rebellion only to be betrayed and executed by Xiang Liang and his nephew Xiang Yu
column7: who launched their own rebellion from the city.

column1: When the Grand Canal was completed
column2: Suzhou found itself strategically located on a major trade route. In the course of the history of China
column3: it has been a metropolis of industry and commerce on the southeastern coast of China. During the Tang dynasty
column4: the great poet Bai Juyi constructed the Shantang Canal (better known as "Shantang Street") to connect the city with Tiger Hill for tourists. In AD 1035
column5: the Suzhou Confucian Temple was founded by famed poet and writer Fan Zhongyan. It became a venue for the imperial civil examinations and then developed into the modern Suzhou High School in the 1910s.

column2: the advancing Jin army from the north ransacked the city. This was followed by the Mongol invasion in 1275. In 1356
column3: Suzhou became the capital of Zhang Shicheng
column4: one of the leaders of the Red Turban Rebellion against the Yuan dynasty and the self-proclaimed King of Wu. In 1367
column5: Zhang's Nanjing-based rival Zhu Yuanzhang took the city after a 10-month siege. Zhu – who was soon to proclaim himself the first emperor of the Ming Dynasty – demolished the royal city in the center of Suzhou's walled city and imposed crushing taxes on the city and prefecture's powerful families. Despite the heavy taxation and the resettlement of some of Suzhou's prominent citizens' to the area of Hongwu's capital at Nanjing
column6: Suzhou was soon prosperous again. During the early Ming
column7: Suzhou Prefecture supervised the Yangtze shoals which later became Shanghai's Chongming Island. For centuries the city
column8: with its surroundings as an economic base
column9: represented an extraordinary source of tax revenue.When the shipwrecked Korean official Choe Bu had a chance to see much of Eastern China from Zhejiang to Liaoning on his way home in 1488
column10: he described Suzhou in his travel report as exceeding every other city. Many of the area's private gardens were constructed by the gentry of the Ming and Qing dynasties. The Taipings captured the city in 1860
column12: and many of its former buildings and gardens were "almost... a heap of ruins" by the time of their recovery by Charles Gordon's Ever-Victorious Army in November 1863. Nonetheless
column14: its population was estimated to have recovered to about 500
column16: which remained stable for the next few decades. In the late 19th century
column17: the town was particularly known for its wide range of silks and its Chinese-language publishing industry. The town was first opened to direct foreign trades by the Treaty of Shimonoseki ending the First Sino-Japanese War and by the most favored nation clauses of earlier unequal treaties with the Great Powers. The new expatriates opened a European-and-Chinese school in 1900 and the Suzhou railway station
column20: 1906. Just prior to the World War I
column21: there were 7000 silk looms in operation
column22: as well as a cotton mill and a large trade in rice.

column5: the city walls ran in a circuit of about 10 miles (16 km) with four large suburbs lying outside. The Japanese invaded in 1937

column1: The urban core of Suzhou is informally called the "Old Town". It is Gusu District. Suzhou Industrial Park is to the east of the old town
column2: and Suzhou High & New Technology Development Zone is to the west. In 2000
column3: the original Wu County was divided into two districts including Xiangcheng and Wuzhong. They now form the northern and southern parts of the city of Suzhou.In 2012
column4: the original Wujiang City became Wujiang District of Suzhou City.

column1: Suzhou is on the Lake Tai Plain south of the Yangtze River
column2: about 100 km (60 mi) to the west of Shanghai and just over 200 km (120 mi) east of Nanjing.

column1: Suzhou has a four-season humid subtropical climate with hot
column2: humid summers and cool
column3: cloudy
column4: damp winters with occasional snowfall (Köppen climate classification Cfa). Northwesterly winds blowing from Siberia during winter can cause temperatures to fall below freezing at night
column5: while southerly or southwesterly winds during the summer can push temperatures above 35 °C (95 °F). The hottest temperature recorded since 1951 was at 41.0 °C (106 °F) on 7 August 2013
column6: and the lowest at −9.8 °C (14 °F) on 16 January 1958.

column1: Baodai Bridge stretches across the Tantai Lake in the suburbs of Suzhou. To raise money to finance the bridge
column2: the magistrate donated his expensive belt
column3: hence the name. The bridge was first built in 806 A.D. in the Tang Dynasty and has 53 arches with a length of 317 meters. It was made out of stone from Jinshan Mountain and is the longest standing bridge of its kind in China. The bridge was included on the list of national monuments (resolution 5-285) in 2001.

column1: Tiger Hill is known for its natural environment and historical sites. The hill is so named because it is said to look like a crouching tiger. Another legend states that a white tiger appeared on the hill to guard it following the burial The hill has been a tourist destination for hundreds
column2: if not thousands
column3: of years
column4: as is evident from the poetry and calligraphy carved into rocks on the hill. The Song Dynasty poet
column5: Su Shi said
column6: "It is a lifelong pity if having visited Suzhou you did not visit Tiger Hill."

column2: built in 961
column3: is a Chinese pagoda built on Tiger Hill in Suzhou. It has several other names
column4: including the "Leaning Tower of China" (as referred to by historian O.G. Ingles) and the Yunyan Temple Tower. The tower rises to a height of 47 m (154 ft). It is a seven-story octagonal building built with blue bricks. In more than a thousand years the tower has gradually slanted due to forces of nature. Now the top and bottom of the tower vary by 2.32 meters. The entire structure weighs some 7
column6: 000 kilograms (15
column9: supported by internal brick columns. However
column10: the tower leans roughly 3 degrees due to the cracking of two supporting columns.Beisi Pagoda or North Temple Pagoda is a Chinese pagoda at Bao'en Temple in Suzhou. It rises nine stories in a height of 76 m (249 ft). It is the tallest Chinese pagoda south of the Yangtze river.

column1: Twin Pagodas (simplified Chinese: 苏州双塔; traditional Chinese: 蘇州雙塔) lie in the Dinghui Temple Lane in the southeastern corner of the city proper of Suzhou. They are artistic and natural as they are close at hand. One of them is called "Clarity-Dispensing Pagoda
column2: and the other, the Beneficence Pagoda"; they are in the same form of architecture. There are many legends about this one-thousand-year-old pagodas. It is charming that the exquisite and straight Twin Pagoda look like two inserted writing brushes. There was originally a single-story house with three rooms just like a writing brush holder with the shadows of the two pagodas reclining on its roof at sunset. To the east of the pagoda is a square five-story bell building built in the Ming Dynasty which appears exactly like a thick ink stick. So there is a saying that "the Twin Pagodas are as writing brushes while the bell building as ink stick".

column1: Suzhou's economy is based primarily on its large manufacturing sector—China's second largest—including iron and steel
column2: IT and electronic equipment
column3: and textile products. The city's service sector is notably well-developed
column4: primarily owing to tourism
column5: which brought in a total of RMB 152 billion of revenue in 2013. Suzhou's overall GDP exceeded RMB 1.3 trillion in 2013 (up 9.6 percent from the year previous).The city is also one of China's foremost destinations for foreign investment
column6: based on its relative proximity to Shanghai and comparatively low operating costs. The municipal government has enacted various measures to encourage FDI in a number of manufacturing (e.g. pharmaceutical
column7: electronic goods
column10: research services) sectors. Included among these measures is a preferential tax policy for limited partnership venture capital enterprises in the Suzhou Industrial Park.

column1: The Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) is the largest cooperative project between the Chinese and Singaporean governments. It is beside Jinji Lake
column2: which lies to the east of the Suzhou Old City. On 26 February 1994
column3: Vice Premier Li Lanqing and Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew represented China and Singapore respectively in signing the Agreement to jointly develop Suzhou Industrial Park (originally called the Singapore Industrial Park). The project officially commenced on 12 May in the same year. SIP has a jurisdiction area of 288 km2 (111 sq mi)
column4: of which
column5: the China-Singapore cooperation area covers 80 km2 (31 sq mi) with a planned residential population of 1.2 million.SIP is home to the Suzhou Dushu Lake Science and Education Innovation District
column6: an area of universities and higher education institutions
column7: including Soochow University and Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University. Suzhou Industrial Park is also a popular residential district for many foreigners who work and live in Suzhou
column8: as well as 'new Suzhou' residents who migrated to the area in search of work opportunities.

column1: Suzhou is on the Shanghai-Nanjing corridor which carries three parallel railways. Suzhou railway station
column2: near the city center
column3: is among the busiest passenger stations in China. It is served by the Beijing–Shanghai railway (mostly "conventional" trains to points throughout China) and the Shanghai-Nanjing intercity railway (high-speed D- and G-series trains providing frequent service primarily between Shanghai and Nanjing). It takes only 25 minutes to reach Shanghai railway station on the fastest G-series trains and less than 1 hour to Nanjing.
